question: ...at the top of the stretch it's Cozy Girl in front with Backtrack coming on... Cozy Girl by a length, Backtrack closing...
answer: Come on. Stay up there, Cozy Girl...

question: At the eighth pole it's Cozy Girl by half a length... Backtrack closing...
answer: Dig in, Cozy Girl... Roper go.

question: It's Cozy Girl holding on... Cozy Girl and Backtrack...
answer: I'm en route. E.T.A. in five. Stay up there, Girl...

question: Cozy Girl in front by a neck... Now a head...
answer: Where's the damn wire?!

question: Here comes the wire... and... Backtrack gets up in the last jump. Cozy girl a very game second.
answer: SHIT!

question: SHIT!
answer: Hi, Roper.

question: Hi, Kimura. Where's the command post?
answer: The suspect came in shortly after the bank opened. Botched robbery. A teller hit the silent alarm. He took seven hostages. Shot one -- the guard. He's still alive. So far he's asked for...

question: ...a car.
answer: That's right, and a plane waiting at the airport. If he doesn't...

question: ...get 'em, he's going to start shooting hostages in five minutes...
answer: That's right.

question: What's the suspect's name?
answer: Earl.

question: Hello, guys.
answer: Hello, Roper. Glad you could join us.

question: Do we have a profile on Mr. Earl?
answer: This guy is no genius.

question: They're not usually graduate students.
answer: SWAT wants to go in.

question: I have to go face to face.
answer: No -- you can't do that.

question: You got 7 hostages in there, 1 of them's wounded -- We don't know how bad it is -- The guy ripped the phone out -- SWAT said he's got a gun to the head of a female hostage. If SWAT makes entry now, you're gonna lose 1 hostage, maybe 2. I gotta go in. Maybe I can see what's going on in there.
answer: I don't know.

question: He's never offed anybody. His rap doesn't show any violence.
answer: Not that we know of.

question: We don't know how much time we have. If I can get in to talk to him -- maybe we won't lose anyone.
answer: Maybe we can get a throw phone in there.

question: Hi, Earl, I'm Scott Roper. Wanna donut? I ate the glazed but there's a bunch of chocolate and a -- I'm a negotiator, Earl. I don't carry a weapon.
answer: Where's the car?

question: I need to get something straight first. Who's the manager? When did you start keeping longer hours? Really! Because I've been thinking of moving to this branch. It would be really convenient for me --
answer: HEY, SHUT UP! Do you want me to start killing people?!

question: It's my job to see that no one gets killed, Earl... Including you.
answer: Then where's my FUCKING car!

question: I'm getting it, Earl, but we have to do this the right way. First I need you to point that gun away from -- What's your name? Point the gun away from Debbie.
answer: Debbie's brains are going to be splattered all over the floor if I don't see a car in five minutes!

question: Alright! But let's be clear about one thing. If you kill someone, I can't help you. The SWAT guys will take you out.
answer: What are my chances of getting out of here?

question: Not bad. Last month, a guy robbed a bank in Daly City... How ya doin'? ...Cops gave him a car, and he lost them on the freeway.
answer: Really?

question: Absolutely. Bank robbers are generally your smartest criminals. He didn't kill anybody, though. This is gonna hurt.
answer: Hey, leave him alone. What are you doing?

question: It's part of my negotiator's oath. If there's an injured party and I can help them, I'm duty bound by my oath to do that. You can shoot me if you want, but the next negotiator in here is going to tell you the same thing. I'll be right back, Earl. Point that gun away from Debbie. Give me your gun. I haven't had to shoot anyone in three years. Because this strung-out junkie is too stupid to get out of this without killing somebody.
answer: HEY, WHAT THE FUCK ARE YOU DOING OUT THERE!

question: As a rule, I need one hostage released as show of good faith. Give me Debbie.
answer: Take the old guy.

question: The Old Guy? What kind of show of faith is that? I want Debbie.
answer: Am I gettin' the car?

question: You're gettin' the car.
answer: Take them.

question: That was fine, Earl. Now I'm going to get your car. Oh, there's one last thing.
answer: What?!

question: You want a convertible or hardtop? Hardtop. Manual or automatic?
answer: Automatic.

question: You got it.
answer: I give up! I give up!

question: There's one for the front page.
answer: Ronnie, why are you torturing me? I can't live without you.

question: Don't start.
answer: This baseball player you're going out with... He's no good for you.

question: Really?! He's a wonderful guy. He makes two million a year, and he worships me.
answer: I worship you.

question: You worship yourself.
answer: Ronnie, forget this what's-his-name.

question: Greg.
answer: Did you know he's already got a bad knee? In another 10 years you're going to be pushing him around in a wheelchair.

question: You know what I think? I think you only want me now, because I'm with somebody else.
answer: Who cares what you think. I want you back and that's all that matters. Let me take you out tomorrow night... Pleeease.

question: I'm going out with Greg tomorrow.
answer: This Greg is really getting in my way. Please. I'm begging you.

question: Oh, I've got to get a shot of this.
answer: Hey, that's my car. Hey, Baffert, what's the story for tonight?

question: Hey, that's my car. Hey, Baffert, what's the story for tonight?
answer: Floor seats.

question: You're my hero.
answer: Dinner's on you.

question: Deal.
answer: He just walked into my office. The Chief says, "Good work this morning. Congratulations."

question: Tell him to give me a raise.
answer: He says, "Thank you very much." I'll discuss it with him right now... Good-bye, Chief. Roper.

question: What?
answer: Are you going to make this hard for me?

question: Depends. What's up?
answer: There's been some concern about you continuing to work without back-up.

question: Define concern.
answer: What if you die and no one can do what you do as well as you do it?

question: Your concern is heartwarming.
answer: It's been decided that you take on another partner and train him to be able to take over for you.

question: Is that what the guy in the Sunday School suit is doing outside?
answer: His name's Kevin McCall. Every Metro Captain agrees that he's their top sharp-shooter and most likely to succeed.

question: Let me see that. Tested high on his intellectual aptitude... Not as high as me but... National marksman finalist... Attended N. Y. C... Went to college. Very impressive. F.B.I. sniper school... Mayorial commendation. "Additional Skills" Great, send him to the Marines. This guy's not a negotiator. He'll quit in two weeks.
answer: You let us worry about that.

question: Is there going to be an expression of your appreciation?
answer: What kind of appreciation are we talking about?

question: The financial kind. I figure I'm going to be working extra hours. All sorts of overtime... training sessions... Not to mention the extra stress...
answer: What do you think would be in order?

question: Like ahh... I don't know... Five thousand dollars.
answer: Okay, I think I could swing that.

question: And a car.
answer: Hey, you just got a five thousand dollar raise. Get a car of your own.

question: You know you've got nothing but cars down there in impound.
answer: Impound isn't a rent-a-car company.

question: The car is part of the deal.
answer: What happened to your Trans Am?

question: Repoed this morning.
answer: I'll provide you with transportation.

question: And even if this doesn't work, I want all the money. These SWAT guys don't have the temperament. They don't have the background... Hey, glad to meet you. I've heard nothing but good things about you...
answer: Same here. I've watched you in action. Very impressive.

question: You've got a lot of hard work ahead of you if you want to be a negotiator.
answer: I'm ready to do it. And I'm going to be here more than two weeks.

question: Don't go reading my lips, man. That's an intrusion. Save that shit for the sniper school. Comprende?
answer: Sorry... Habit.

question: You ever been in a hostage situation?
answer: Only at the very end.

question: How do you feel after a shooting.
answer: Like it had to be done.

question: It rarely has to be done.
answer: I've rarely shot anyone.

question: SWAT is a lifesaving unit, you know.
answer: I know.

question: Try to remember that. Okay, "Dead Eye", lesson one... Extract that pen cap without touching or moving the bottle.
answer: What's the point of this?

question: Mind if we make a stop on the way? We busted Frank Antonucci on possession. He gave us a lead on that Polk Street jewelry heist.
answer: "Phoney Frank"? Don't waste your time. He'd tell you his granny was in on the Kennedy assassination if he could dodge a collar.

question: I still gotta do it. Wasting time is half my job.
answer: Yeah, okay.

question: This SWAT guy might be a good idea. He may be able to take a little pressure off you. I worry about you.
answer: You worried about me, too? The chief's worried about me. Solis is worried about me. Maybe you guys should start some kind of organization.

question: Speaking of which. I saw you talking to Ronnie this morning. Why can't you get it back together with her. You've gotta be out of your mind not to get with that one.
answer: It's not me. It's her. She's going out with this baseball player -- Greg Barnett.

question: No shit! He's good!
answer: Fuck him. He swings at anything in the dirt. I could strike him out.

question: Don't give up on her. You're getting to the age when you ought to be thinking about these things.
answer: Yep, my rheumatism's been acting up.

question: This is it. Space 742.
answer: Then he didn't say 742. He must have said 724 or something, because this can't be right. Oh man! What am I, Red Foxx? I'm not riding in this shit. I can't roll in no shit like this.

question: Where's the stereo?
answer: Fuck the stereo. What's that smell?

question: Apartment 306.
answer: You want me to go up with you?

question: Nah, It probably won't turn up anything. I'm just gonna talk to him.
answer: Good. I don't want to be late. You want anything on the game?

question: What's the line?
answer: It was Warriors plus 6 this morning.

question: I'll take half of your action.
answer: Who is it?

question: It's Lieutenant Sam Baffert from the San Francisco Police Department.
answer: What happened? Is there a problem?

question: May I come in? I would just like to ask you a couple of questions. Count Basie?
answer: Duke Ellington. "Things Ain't What They Used To Be", recorded July 30,

question: Yeah... Yeah... Now I can hear it. Where did you find an old recording like that?
answer: Used record shop down on Turk Street. I was in there looking for some Robert Johnson. Memories... Memory Lane or something...

question: I've got to stop in there... Mr. Korda, do you know Frank Antonucci?
answer: You mean Frank who owns the bakery down the street?

question: No, this is a different Frank. This is a man who deals in jewelry. Stolen jewelry usually. You wouldn't know anybody like that?
answer: I certainly wouldn't.

question: Could I please have a little water?
answer: Of course.

question: The reason I'm asking you is because we arrested him with some stolen jewelry. It was traced to the robbery of a store down on Polk Street. He said he was fencing it for you.
answer: There's obviously some mistake. I have a cousin who has had run-ins with the law. Perhaps for his own reasons he entangled me in this... situation.

question: This cousin of yours... What's his name?
answer: Clarence Teal. Your cough seems to be better.

question: Thank you. Well, I'm on my way to the game. I appreciate your cooperation, Mr. Korda.
answer: Lieutenant... Do you believe that story about Robert Johnson...? That he made a deal with the devil at the crossroads?

question: Get an ambulance!
answer: Yes sir. Every resource will be brought to bear. We will find this guy... Yeah, he's here now. I'll tell him. The chief says to tell you how sorry he is. He knew Sam Baffert was a good man.

question: He said he was just going up to talk to him. He said... I want to be put on this case.
answer: I can't do that.

question: I want to be put on this case.
answer: You know I can't assign you to this. You're much too close to it. You were much too close to Sam. The department will take care of it.

question: Who's running it?
answer: Roper...

question: Who's running it!
answer: Kimura and Glass will head the investigation. Scott. Go home. Get some sleep.

question: Just a minute. Hey.
answer: Hey yourself. Came by to see Troy.

question: A little late for that, Scottie. He's asleep. Jack Daniels?
answer: I'm not drunk. Yet.

question: Maybe you should be.
answer: You heard.

question: Yeah. I'm sorry.
answer: Can I come in? That a new picture?

question: About 4 months old. I'm working in a new style.
answer: Hey, Troy. How ya doin' boy? He heard my voice. How's the good dog. I miss you buddy. You miss me? He misses me. I won't stay long. I had to talk to someone.

question: You don't usually talk to anyone when you're hurting.
answer: It was my fault. I was right downstairs. I should have gone up with him.

question: Scott, You can't save everyone.
answer: I've proved that, didn't I? Oh, hell, forget it. This won't work.

question: What do you want from me?
answer: Something I guess I can't have anymore.

question: Don't try to make me feel guilty. The whole time we were together, you went out of your way to prove you didn't need me. Now, suddenly, for one night, you need me again. I can't do it. I can't be more than your friend. Because I know what will happen. In a few weeks you'll be back on top, and you'll shut me out just as soon as you don't need me again.
answer: You think I didn't need you?

question: If you did, you never showed it.
answer: Ronnie... You expecting someone? This day just keeps getting better.

question: They're on the table where you always leave them.
answer: I was just leaving.

question: If you weren't family I'd kill you. You told Antonucci that shit came from me.
answer: So that we could get the best price. He's got respect for you. He's gonna try to lowball me, Mike.

question: You fucking idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.
answer: I'm sorry, Mike. I never heard of LaMarra flipping on anyone before. He said he had the cops paid off. Antonucci never flipped on anyone before. He had the cops paid off.

question: Not the fucking cop that showed up at my door!
answer: What happened, Mike.

question: You don't want to know.
answer: I'm sorry, Mike.

question: God damn it! I still needed to case that fucking store. It's too risky to show my face now.
answer: I got a couple thousand bucks. You could leave town.

question: Leave town? They're going to know me in fucking Des Moines now!... They got over ten million in jewels in that place. That's freedom, man. I could go anywhere I want.
answer: Did you kill him, Mike? I'm sorry, Mike. I'm really sorry...

question: What do you got on Korda?
answer: We ran a search on relatives. He has a cousin in town -- Clarence Teal. Smalltime thief. Last known address was on Pine Street. He moved out a month ago. We've got a couple leads on him to check out.

question: Did you check out DMV for any vehicles registration?
answer: Being faxed over now.

question: How about the record room for any incident reports? He might be a victim. We can get medical records. Check with burglary detail and see if anyone else knows him, knows his habits.
answer: Roper...

question: And what about bars? We can talk to neighbors to see what bars he frequents.
answer: Roper, we're into it...

question: You guys are doing good work.
answer: I'm sorry about your friend. I had a friend in SWAT killed. I know how it can be.

question: I appreciate your concern. Let's leave it at that. I don't see much progress here. Very nice... You get an "A". Notice... No force required. No damage. So, McCall, how come you ended up in San Francisco?
answer: They recruited me. Promised me fast advancement.

question: Recruited you from where?
answer: National Marksman Competition.

question: With your qualifications you must have had a lot of offers. Why here?
answer: Furthest point I could find from New York.

question: You don't like New York?
answer: Spent my whole life there. I just wanted to get out for a while.

question: You'd never been out of New York?
answer: Been to Toronto. My mother was born there.

question: How did you like Toronto?
answer: It was okay.

question: You're a real excitable sort, aren't you?
answer: You caught me on an "up" day. How about you? How did you end up in San Francisco?

question: I grew up in Oakland... Crossed the Bay Bridge and here I was. So you're looking for "fast advancement".
answer: Is there something wrong with that?

question: I'm not sure. Roper. Metro Division. Hostage Negotiator. Give me the short version. Which apartment? How are we gonna get him out of there?
answer: We could fill it with water.

question: Have you evacuated anyone? Is the hostage injured? Well, there's a good amount of agreement on that.
answer: I'll take "highground" until SWAT gets here. I can get a good sight-line from that roof across the street.

question: Remember, Quick Draw, we're trying to limit the force here.
answer: I know my job.

question: I'm coming in. I'm not armed.
answer: Stay the fuck out of here!

question: I know how you feel, Ray.
answer: You don't know shit, and I suggest you leave.

question: I can't leave, Ray. It's part of my negotiator's oath. Once I'm in the room with the hostage, I have to stay.
answer: You don't want to see what I'm going to do to her.

question: Let me show you something, Ray. holds it up so Raymond can see it. Same thing happened to me, man. She cheated on me, but I forgave her. You know why?
answer: I ain't interested in your life story.

question: Because I was partially to blame. I wasn't around as much as I should have been. I forgot how to love her.
answer: She's the one to blame. Not me.

question: Ray, think about how she looked when you married her. Think about how happy you were. Don't lose that, man. Don't give up everything.
answer: What am I giving up? I'm laid off last year. I'm down to my last unemployment check. I'm out on the streets looking for work and this bitch is banging some asshole in my bed. I'm down at Consolidated and I'm begging. I'm saying I'll take half my pay. Eight years, man. I don't even have to work the loading docks anymore. I'll do maintenance. "We're cutting back. We're streamlining, Ray. West Central's running things now. It's out of our hands" Fuck them! Fuck them! FUCK THEM! I'm gonna kill her and then I'm gonna kill myself, 'cause I don't wanna live anymore.

question: Ray, if you walk out of here with me, I'll get you a job.
answer: Doing what? Cleaning toilets?

question: I can't guarantee you what it will be. But I swear on my life, I'll find you work.
answer: And why the fuck would you do that for me?

question: Not for you, Ray. For me. A close friend of mine was killed this week. The way I figure it, I stop you from doin' what you said, I'm one up on body count.
answer: Who the fuck are you, Mother Teresa?

question: My name's Scott Roper.
answer: I need my coat.

question: NOOOO!! WHO THE FUCK DO YOU THINK YOU ARE? Do you think because the police department issued you a sniper rifle, it makes you God! What the fuck goes on in your head?
answer: SWAT is a lifesaving unit, remember? I just saved a life. Yours.

question: You think I've never had a gun pulled on me?! You think every fucking time someone pulls a gun they use it?!
answer: Eighty-five percent of domestic disturbances of this nature end in murder/suicide.

question: Not the ones I'm at.
answer: Sorry. My mistake.

question: Come on. Let's go for a drink.
answer: I don't really like to drink.

question: You have to. It's a tradition.
answer: Well, if I have to, I have to.

question: You got a girlfriend?
answer: Why? You like my ass?

question: Better than your pool game. You wouldn't want to put a small wager on this, would you?
answer: I don't gamble. Yeah, I've got a girlfriend.

question: You living together?
answer: She's back in Jersey... going to graduate school.

question: Explain how that works.
answer: She's going to come here when she graduates and then we're gonna get married.

question: She grow up in Livingtston, too?
answer: No, no, no... She's from Hoboken.

question: Oh, "city girl". Don't you ever long for companionship with her such a long way away in New Jersey?
answer: We see each other every couple of months.

question: Every couple of months, huh? That's a lot of commitment. I admire that.
answer: Do you really?

question: No. Actually I think it's fucking crazy, I don't know if I could do it.
answer: Thanks for clearing that up. I hear your former girlfriend is going out with Greg Barnett.

question: Where did you hear that?
answer: Around. Barnett's tough competition.

question: Yeah, well that's a sore subject, and therefore out of bounds to a young sprout of a hostage negotiator under my tutelage. Lesson two, "Dead Eye"... should have been lesson one. Never exchange yourself for a hostage.
answer: I think I can handle that one.

question: Yeah, you think so, but it comes up. Zack, another round. My partner gave himself in exchange for a ten year old girl. He got caught in the crossfire. Two dead. My partner and the bad guy... Weird thing is, if he was alive, he'd probably do it again. Some people never learn. You think you can learn, McCall?
answer: I think so. I'm Officer McCall, what's going on? H... how can I help you? Tell me what... I feel stupid talking to a dummy.

question: What did you think? I'm going to let you practice on real people? First things is, don't say, "What's going on?" Everybody knows what's going on. I come into this situation, I say, "I'm glad to see nobody's hurt. That's good. I'm here to help you." Second
answer: No.

question: It'll come. Try again.
answer: My name's McCall. I'm a hostage negotiator. I'm here to help you.

question: How are you going to help me?
answer: Tell me what you need.

question: I need you to bring me the scumbag who ran off with my wife so I can cut off his nuts.
answer: I can't do that.

question: Then get out of my face you worthless piece of frogshit.
answer: Is all the name calling necessary.

question: Nah, I just throw that in because I enjoy it.
answer: So what do I say to this guy?

question: You could say something like, "Tell me what the scumbag's name is. Maybe we can work something out."
answer: What? Bring somebody in so he can cut his nuts off?

question: If you want to be a successful negotiator, you've got to learn to lie.
answer: I'm not good at lying.

question: Get good at it.
answer: It's against my nature.

question: You know the ten commandments?
answer: Yes.

question: What's the first commandment?
answer: Thou shall have no other God before me.

question: Okay, forget that. What's the main one.
answer: You tell me.

question: Thou shall not kill... You've killed, right?
answer: Yes.

question: Why?
answer: To save lives.

question: So why would you hesitate to lie to save lives? Let's try it again.
answer: My name's McCall. I'm unarmed.

question: Okay, stop. Close your eyes. What did you see?
answer: A dirtbag behind the counter holding a sawed-off. A Berretta nine millimeter in his belt. A female hostage, red dress, on the floor in front of the cereal display. Male hostage, jeans and blue checked shirt, three feet to her right. Another male hostage, white pants, green shirt, Nikes, laying in front of the magazine rack. A female dirtbag with a gun under her shirt, sitting against the beer cooler, trying to pass herself off as a hostage, and there's a special on toilet-paper, four for a buck twenty-nine.

question: Very good. You've got good eyes. That's important.
answer: Was that your partner? Why did he do it?

question: Because he knew the little girl had zero chance of survival and his chances would be a little better... We had a plan, but SWAT opened up too early. He got caught in the crossfire. Let's move on... Notice this. Always use the eyes to keep the connection. It almost like hypnosis. That's the most important thing. Create a connection. You're always on their side... You know why I like the track?
answer: You're a compulsive gambler?

question: Because there are a multitude of possibility's. Everything is there to see if you know what to look for. You have to read the conditions, just like in a hostage situation. See the four horse. Dropping in class. No works. Front wraps. Looks like he's broken down. But notice the woman in the sun hat. She's the owner. She wouldn't have come if her horse was broken down. He's live. We use him. See the favorite? Tail up. Washy. He doesn't want to run today. Cross him off... Now the Six looks good. On his toes. Coat shiny. This trainer/jockey combo does well. We can't leave him out. What do you think?
answer: I have two words for you... Seek help.

question: I have three words for you... Ex-ac- ta. I bought you a four-six exacta box. You owe me twenty bucks.
answer: I do.

question: How you doin', Marv? We need the 4 and 6 to finish to first and second.
answer: Fine. I'm told that newspaper photographer is your former girlfriend.

question: Ronnie... Yeah, so.
answer: Now she's going out with Greg Barnett?

question: So what do you want?... An autograph.
answer: I don't know why she'd pick him over you. I'm just practicing my lying.

question: Still needs work.
answer: You're right. I'll never be as good a liar as you.

question: Okay, we're in good shape. We're in good shape.
answer: The 6 horse is last.

question: That's okay. That's his style.
answer: To run last?

question: To run late! The favorite's fading. I told you he wasn't going to run today... The four horse has got the lead!
answer: The 6 horse is still last.

question: We won!
answer: We lost.

question: We won.
answer: How much you wanna bet?

question: You want to bet on whether you won your bet? This is getting sick.
answer: Yes! That's eight hundred bucks.

question: How long you been coming here?
answer: About six years. My partner took me.

question: Is it always like this?
answer: Occasionally you lose. Roper here. I'm on my way. We gotta go.

question: This will take time to setup. I'll have to get authorizations. Okay, you relax, and I'll --
answer: What do we got?

question: 32 minutes ago the silent alarm went off, then the fire alarm. A unit was a block away, and the suspect got trapped inside.
answer: Any verification on numbers.

question: We've only seen and talked to one suspect. He calls himself "Joe". There's two jewelers, two salespeople, the manager, a security guard, and an elderly woman. This particular store is where they do a lot of jewelry making and repair. They have anywhere from 8 to 10 million in raw stones on any given day, so they sure as shit didn't just wander in. They knew what they were coming for.
answer: What have you promised them?

question: Just that I'd talk to my superiors.
answer: Any good points of entry?

question: My name's Roper. How are you people doing in there? Solis is off the job now, Joe. I'm the guy authorized to give you whatever you want. That's right, but first I need to come down there to talk to you.
answer: You don't have to come here.

question: Yes, I do. That way there's no misunderstandings. I need to make sure no one's hurt, then we can take care of business.
answer: Alright, Roper. You want to come... come.

question: Good. I won't be armed. We gotta operate on trust here. We're going to wrap this up and have you guys out of here as soon as possible.
answer: Stay there.

question: I'm going to put my hands down, okay.
answer: Are you in charge, Roper?

question: Yep.
answer: I want a car. Like a four wheel drive. I want it in perfect condition. I want a uniformed cop to drive it up right here. I want him to leave the engine running and walk to the end of the street. Then we'll come out. I don't want any remote control devices in it. I know all the tricks. If it's not in perfect condition, and I mean if its even low on wiper fluid, I'm going to kill somebody and we're gonna start again. I want a plane waiting at the airport. I'll tell them where I want to go when I get there.

question: Is that all?
answer: For now that's all.

question: You'll get it. But, Joe, I want you to do something for me. Let me take a look around inside. Make sure everybody's okay.
answer: No. You just do shit for me right now.

question: Joe, I'm doing a lot for you. I think you could give me something to cement the deal... One hostage.
answer: I'll give you something. In fifteen minutes it'll be a bigger piece. I assume there are no "misunderstanding".

question: This fucker's not answering.
answer: There's your answer. He's smart.

question: He's cutting down the visibility.
answer: And doing a very good job of it. Come on. Give us one clean shot. They're out.

question: It's Korda.
answer: They switched clothes.

question: Hold your fire! Hold your fire! Shit! Where'd that shot come from? Hold your fire!
answer: He's got the girl.

question: You weren't at the press conference.
answer: I wanted to get this out of the way.

question: You got a bet on the game tonight?
answer: As a matter of fact, I do.

question: It's already started.
answer: I was going to catch the last half on TV.

question: Good-night.
answer: You having dinner with Mr. Baseball?

question: Greg is on a road trip. I was just going to make some pasta.
answer: That kind with the garlic and the oil that I like so much?

question: No. The kind from Kraft, with the macaroni and the cheese.
answer: I've been craving that stuff all week.

question: What do you think?
answer: Mmm, needs a little something.

question: What are you talking about? This is it. This is the stuff right here. Well, maybe just a pinch more sugar.
answer: Yeah that's it.

question: Why don't you just stick your finger in and stir it up.
answer: Scottie...

question: What would you say if I quit gambling?
answer: I'd say you'd be miserable... It's not the gambling. It's what the gambling got in the way of. The track is where you'd take your troubles instead of sharing them with me... Scottie, remember the day you lost that hostage in union square. You came over that night and we made mad, crazy love. But I didn't even know what happened... 'til I heard it on the news the next morning.

question: It's because I wanted to keep you away from that world.
answer: It's not that world. It's your world. It's part of who you are.

question: Veronica, it's not easy for me... I don't know if I can change overnight. But what I'm telling you is that I want to share everything with you, because I don't ever want to be without you again. What about Greg? What are you gonna tell him?
answer: It's okay. We broke up.

question: When?
answer: Just now.

question: How ya doin', man?
answer: You gotta do something for me... this fucker, Roper, he's gotta girlfriend. She works at the newspaper. I want you to take care of her.

question: Hey, Michael, that's not my thing.
answer: You gotta do this for me. I'm in here because of you.

question: Man, what's this about? Ya know, you were robbing a store. It wasn't personal. It was his job.
answer: Fuck you! You know what he did to me?!... He held a gun to my head and said he should kill me right then... He made me... You do this for me Clarence.

question: Don't make do it, Mike.
answer: Are you going to turn on me too? Who helped you when you were strung out? Who gave you money? Who bailed you out of jail?

question: I won't get away with it.
answer: Nobody knows who you are. Make it look like a robbery.

question: You okay?! Stay. Shut the fuck up! Get on your radio and get the police here.
answer: Dons a smug expression and takes a seat. He picks up his receiver as Roper picks up his.

question: If you try again to hurt me or anyone I know, I'm going to have you killed.
answer: What in the world are you talking about, Mr. Roper?

question: Here's a picture of your cousin Clarence. That gentleman standing over him is the coroner.
answer: I used to have an apartment, a car, jewelry. I had a fucking eight thousand dollar watch. Now look what I have. You're threatening me? You think I give a fuck? You think you can scare me off? Why don't you come in here and kick my ass? Get some of your guard friends in here to help. I'd like that. He really shook you up, didn't he?... I've got ten years worth of appeals to figure out how to fuck with you. Who knows? Maybe some scumbag lawyer will get me out on a technicality. You came here to threaten me? That's a laugh. Maybe you should BEG me... Go ahead. Get down on your knees.

question: Why is he up there? Who is he? Another negotiator is on his way. What about the doctors?
answer: Get the fuck out of here!

question: I... I'm Kevin. I 'm here to help you, D... Dave.
answer: You can't help me, man. No one can help me. They're controlling my mind.

question: Who's controlling your mind?
answer: Whoa!... The government. They control everybody's mind. You're too fucking stupid to know that?

question: This has nothing to do with Walter.
answer: They want Walter dead!

question: Dave, look at me. Tell me what's wrong.
answer: Particles, man. I feel them all the time. I feel them in my arms and legs man, that's how they punish me.

question: How can I help you with the particles?
answer: It's not just the particles man, it's the whole fucking machine, this is how they get assassins to operate. It's been this way since the cuban missile crisis.

question: They have less power over you if you look into my eyes.
answer: Huh? Huh?

question: We've been onto them for a long time. Let me show you something. See this. I'm jamming them, Dave. I'm jamming their frequency so they can't control your mind anymore. Don't you feel that? You don't have to do what they say. You see, the particles are gone, they can't punish you anymore.
answer: Tell my dad.

question: Tell him what, what do you want me to tell him?
answer: Tell my dad I'm sorry about the watch.

question: I'll tell him. Where does he live. We'll get him on the phone right now.
answer: I hate fucking Springfield.

question: Is that where you're family lives?
answer: I still hear them, man. You can't jam them. They've got the technology, man. They've got the satellites, Jack. They keep shooting beams off those satellites. What power do I have?

question: Give me a twenty dollar four-six exacta. Then give me a fucking four-seven exacta. Come on four horse! Come on Seven horse! Come on four-seven... Come on... Come on... Come on...
answer: It might have happened no matter who was up there.

question: Bullshit! Would it have happened to you?
answer: Maybe... There's one thing you have to remember... You don't create the situations. You can only try to save people from them.

question: I thought I could do it. I was so damn sure of myself. But I didn't know what to say. The words wouldn't come. My mouth turned to mush. You make it look so easy, Roper. But it is not. It's not easy. It's a different job than looking through the rifle scope.
answer: That it is.

question: How many have you lost?
answer: I look at it as how many I've saved. That's the way you've got to look at it.

question: And what about the ones you don't save?
answer: You live with it... and they haunt you. It doesn't leave.

question: And what if you can't live with it?
answer: You've got to decide that for yourself. I've lost three. One of them was my partner. I think about them every time I go into a situation. There's a million people in this city with all kinds of twisted shit going on in their heads, and the bitch of this job is that we expect to go out every day and do the impossible -- to somehow control all this craziness... and we can't. Nobody's faulting you for this, McCall. My advice is you let yourself off the hook.

question: I don't know... I don't know...
answer: Let's get out of here.

question: It has a nice "nose". That's my favorite. Why don't you give us a minute. You like this place?
answer: It's very nice.

question: I guess you realize that there's something special that I want to talk to you about.
answer: There is?

question: For the last week things have been going pretty well between us. I think we've been doing a good job getting intimate and all that stuff...
answer: Yeah?

question: ...Let me just show you.
answer: Scottie, we should think this over before we...

question: Tahiti.
answer: Ohhh... A vacation... Yeah that sounds like a great idea.

question: ...Yeah? Just tryin' to make a living.
answer: I don't know what to tell you, mam, your brother ain't here. Try San Bruno. I'm sorry. Then I don't know where he is.

question: Listen, can I just sign outta here?
answer: Who are you again?

question: Johnny Hawkins. Bail Bonds. I gotta be over at county in fifteen minutes, alright?
answer: Johnny who?

question: It's the criminal justice system. What can I tell ya? It's a mess.
answer: Alright, alright, just sign.

question: If you find him, gimme a call.
answer: Hold on a second here.

question: Is there a problem?
answer: You signed out twice.

question: I what?
answer: Look, why don't you just come on back inside for a second.

question: How come in those foreign movies the young girl is always with some fat, old guy.
answer: In Europe women find older men very sexy.

question: When I get old and fat, I'm moving to Europe.
answer: I forgot to leave food for Paco. He's probably starving.

question: Damn, my eyes are tired from reading that movie.
answer: I'm sorry, Paco. I forgot -- Paco? Paco? Paco, have you been eating my face soap, again? What is it, Scottie?

question: Korda escaped.
answer: And you think he'll...

question: Hey, I'm on edge a little. Let's relax. I'm sure he's just going to try to get out of town. Anyway we leave tomorrow. Why don't we do some of that European movie stuff.
answer: I don't think you're old and fat enough for me.

question: I sent that ahead, wise guy.
answer: Why don't you come back up with me, Ronnie.

question: I think I'll stand out here in the sun.
answer: It's better if you stay inside.

question: Good question. Korda!
answer: Nice of you to make it, Roper. Take your jacket off, put it on the hood. Now, over to the chains, to your left. But first, let's have a look under the tarp. Pull it back. All right, move it.

question: Reaches the the chained area, REVEALING an empty DRY DOCK, easily one hundred feet deep and five hundred long.
answer: Throw in and your piece. And your back up. Walk under the cranes and down the alleyway. At the end, turn right. Building thirty-six.

question: Where the hell are you, McCall?
answer: Right there, Roper.

question: Shit.
answer: Come on in, there's someone just dying to see you.

question: Where is she, Korda? I want to see her.
answer: Walk to the table. Open your shirt.

question: I'm not wearing a wire. This is just between you and me.
answer: Shut the fuck up and do what I say!

question: Satisfied?
answer: Open the bag, dump everything on the table.

question: It's all there.
answer: Spread it out.

question: Only the jewels, Korda, you've got my word.
answer: Show me something. Not that one.

question: Right there, the one in front... yeah, that one. Toss it.
answer: I'm impressed. I didn't think you could do it. What did you have to do, steal them?

question: Yeah.
answer: That's not going to look too good on your service record.

question: I'll worry about that. Let's get on with it.
answer: My sentiments exactly.

question: Stay put.
answer: Clearing the building sees Roper's PICKUP. He runs to it, jumping inside, finding the KEYS in the ignition. He starts the truck, pulling out, just as Roper runs into view.

question: With the truck accelerating towards him he raises and FIRES, two bullet holes in the front WINDSHIELD, missing Korda, the truck still speeding towards him. Roper's gun jams. Roper leaps, sliding forward on the hood, almost falling as he grabs on to the empty window frame and the windshield wiper blades for support, his WEAPON flying from his hand.
answer: Speeds around the buildings and down the alleyways, whipping from side to side, trying to shake Roper off, Roper hanging on for dear life.

question: Give it up, Korda, you got away with nothing! Nothing but a bag of shit! It's all fake! Go on, you stupid fuck, look at it! It's all shit! A hundred dollars worth of glass!
answer: You fuck!!!

question: In the maelstrom lets go his grip, grabbing the upper frame of the window and assisted by the speed of the truck, rolls over the top of the cab, landing in the bed of the truck along with BOXES, LUMBER, and TRASH.
answer: Clears his eyes, looking up, Roper is gone! He LAUGHS hysterically... he knocked him off! Suddenly SEES the approaching dry dock. He jams on the brakes, but it's not enough, the truck racing towards the edge...

question: Lands in a huge pile of CARGO NETS and CARDBOARD BOXES, piled near the edge of the dry dock...
answer: SCREAMS in wide-eyed terror as...
